POR.DRECONTENT:
MRI-R2: Acquisition of Conformal-Oxide Processing module for Microfabrication Central User Facility


The principal objective of this Major Research Instrumentation-Recovery and Reinvestment (MRI-R2) program was to enable the development of nanopatterned conformal oxides for a variety of device applications. To achieve this goal, this grant funding was used in combination with institutional cost-sharing funds to acquire a new processing module comprised of complementary inductively-coupled plasma (ICP) etch and atomic-layer deposition (ALD) tools for the Brown Microelectronics Central User Facility. Specifically, we acquired a new SPTS LPX ICP reactive-ion etcher (RIE) from SPP Process Technology Systems and a Fiji F200 Plasma-Enhanced ALD system from Cambridge Nanotech.

 

Intellectual Merit: This ICP / ALD cluster enables the fabrication of nanopatterned conformal oxides for cutting-edge applications in electronic, fluidic, photonic, and implantable devices. Specifically, this equipment is already helping researchers: (1) deposit high-k dielectrics for nanoelectronic devices; (2) control the dimensions and surface chemistry of nanofluidic channels; (3) pattern and protect optically active materials, including luminescent rare-earth oxides, for light emitters and detectors; and (4) encapsulate implants with bio-compatible coatings that prevent infection and promote tissue growth.

 

Broader impacts: Located in a central user facility with ongoing technical and administrative support, this equipment constitutes a linchpin of the Brown University infrastructure for research training in nanoscale science and engineering. Housed in a publicly accessible cleanroom, this equipment has already been made available to researchers from many university departments, including Engineering, Physics, Chemistry, Biology and Medicine, as well as outside users from local industry and academic institutions via the Materials Research Facilities Network. Furthermore, this program helped to enrich established outreach programs through the NSF sponsored GK-12 “Physical Processes in the Environment” program in the Providence Public School system and the collaborative REU program offered by the Brown Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (MRSEC) and the Leadership Alliance.
